DataElement.preferredName: Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 Second Outcome Spirometry Outcome Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The response that describes the category assigned to the outcome of a test of lung function by evaluating the volume of air expelled within the first second based on the level of total lung capacity.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 Second Outcome
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A test of lung function, the FEV1 is the volume exhaled during the first second of a forced expiratory maneuver started from the level of total lung capacity. It is the most frequently used index for assessing bronchoconstriction or bronchodilatation.:The result of an action.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A test of lung function, the FEV1 is the volume exhaled during the first second of a forced expiratory maneuver started from the level of total lung capacity. It is the most frequently used index for assessing bronchoconstriction or bronchodilatation. (from http://www.spirxpert.com/indices7.htm)

Concepts.definition: A test of lung function, the FEV1 is the volume exhaled during the first second of a forced expiratory maneuver started from the level of total lung capacity. It is the most frequently used index for assessing bronchoconstriction or bronchodilatation.

Property.preferredDefinition: A phenomenon that follows and is caused by some previous phenomenon.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Measurement of the breathing capacity of the lung by means of a spirometer._A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics._A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Being approximately average or within certain limits; conforming with or constituting a norm or standard or level or type or social norm._Distinct from cell or tissue respiration, Respiration is the act of breathing with the lungs and consists of inspiration, or taking ambient air into the lungs, and expiration, or expelling modified air that contains more carbon dioxide than the air taken in. (NCI)

Concepts.definition: Being approximately average or within certain limits; conforming with or constituting a norm or standard or level or type or social norm.

Distinct from cell or tissue respiration, Respiration is the act of breathing with the lungs and consists of inspiration, or taking ambient air into the lungs, and expiration, or expelling modified air that contains more carbon dioxide than the air taken in. (NCI)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The quality of being within reasonable or average limits; not excessive or extreme._Made less in size or amount or degree._Distinct from cell or tissue respiration, Respiration is the act of breathing with the lungs and consists of inspiration, or taking ambient air into the lungs, and expiration, or expelling modified air that contains more carbon dioxide than the air taken in. (NCI)

Concepts.definition: The quality of being within reasonable or average limits; not excessive or extreme.
Made less in size or amount or degree.

Distinct from cell or tissue respiration, Respiration is the act of breathing with the lungs and consists of inspiration, or taking ambient air into the lungs, and expiration, or expelling modified air that contains more carbon dioxide than the air taken in. (NCI)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Intensely bad or unpleasant in degree, quality or extent._Made less in size or amount or degree._Distinct from cell or tissue respiration, Respiration is the act of breathing with the lungs and consists of inspiration, or taking ambient air into the lungs, and expiration, or expelling modified air that contains more carbon dioxide than the air taken in. (NCI)

Made less in size or amount or degree.

Distinct from cell or tissue respiration, Respiration is the act of breathing with the lungs and consists of inspiration, or taking ambient air into the lungs, and expiration, or expelling modified air that contains more carbon dioxide than the air taken in. (NCI)
